awd_titl_txt: A Framework for Predictive Hybrid Models of Turbulence
awd_abstract_narration:
Design and operation of advanced technological systems rely on the ability to predict their behavior using reliable computer simulation. Many important systems including automotive, aeronautic, propulsion, power generation and wind energy systems involve complex fluid flows. However, their reliable simulation is hindered by the fact that the fluid flows in these systems are mostly turbulent. This means that the fluid motion is chaotic and unpredictable. There are currently no accurate and broadly applicable models to describe the effects of turbulence on such flows. Recent approaches to computer modeling of complex turbulent flows could address several fundamental limitations of the previous models and where they have failed to produce accurate simulations of complex turbulent flows. Improving turbulence models are therefore necessary for accurate description of the fluid motion in complex fluid systems. This requires addressing several outstanding challenges in this field of research. The new proposed modeling framework is aimed at addressing these challenges to enable accurate and reliable computer simulation of turbulent flows. This long- sought capability will allow the development of more capable and efficient fluid flow systems, like those in the areas listed above.

It has long been recognized that Reynolds averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) and large eddy simulation (LES) models of turbulence have complementary strengths and weaknesses suggesting their hybridization to produce a more capable model. However, previous hybridization techniques were found to have fundamental flaws. A new hybrid modeling approach eliminates these flaws and forms the basis for the research proposed here. This approach enables the consideration of three additional turbulence modeling challenges, which when addressed will result in highly reliable and broadly applicable hybrid RANS/LES models. These challenges are: the active exchange of energy between the resolved and unresolved turbulence to allow rapid development of resolved fluctuations; the elimination of large errors in LES that arise from the strongly inhomogeneous resolution that is usually necessary in complex fluid systems; and, the generalization of LES models to account for anisotropy of the unresolved turbulence which inevitably arises in hybrid simulations of complex turbulent flows. The result of these developments will be robust predictive hybrid RANS/LES models that will enable technological advances in many systems that involve turbulent fluid flow.

por.por_cntn:
This project was aimed at the development of reliable models for turbulent flows in technologically important scenarios using a hybrid of two modeling techniques, one in which only the mean velocity is simulated (Reynolds Averaged Naver-Stokes models or RANS) and one in which the largest turbulence fluctuations are also simulated (Large Eddy Simulation models or LES). This hybrid RANS/LES approach has been pursued for many years because the two modeling approaches are complimentary. The project addressed a number of technical problems with such hybrid models that arise because of the hybridization and because of shortcomings of the LES models.

One of the most significant accomplishments of this project was the analysis of the interaction of the errors introduces by the numerical discretizations used to solve the LES equations and the subgrid models used in the LES. This analysis showed that the numerical errors can significantly disrupt the dynamics of the resolved turbulence fluctuations when the turbulence is convected through the numerical grid, as occurs in most technologically relevant flows. This problem is exacerbated by spatial changes in the numerical resolution, as is also common in applications. To address this problem, a class of models was developed that depend explicitly on the characteristics of the numerical discretization, and that are designed to eliminate the spurious behaviors, and numerical simulations indicate that they successfully eliminate the anomolies. In addition a theoretical model of the effects of models, discretization and filtering on the results of an LES was developed based on classical turbulence theory. This model will be valuable for efficiently analyzing the quality of proposed combinations of model, discretization and filter, and for optimizing the design of these elements.

Other accomplishments include the development of a novel modeling formulation to represent the effects of the very small scale turbulence that occurs near walls. This formulation is promising, but further development is required to appropriately couple this wall model to the LES of turbulence away from the wall. Together the accomplishments of this project represent significant progress toward the goal of reliable models for the simulation of complex turbulent flows of technological significance.

In addition to the technical contributions, this project supported or partially supported the training of three graduate students in the modeling and simulation of turbulence and in computational science more generally. Two of these students have graduated and are continuing to pursue research in the simulation and modeling of turbulence in their positions as postdoctoral scholars. The third student is continuing his doctoral studies in turbulence modeling.
